data.title: States of Guernsey
data.meta_description: The admission and stay of persons other than British citizens is governed by statute in the form of various United Kingdom Immigration Acts extended by order in council to the Bailiwick of Guernsey, in effect, making them Bailiwick law.
data.text:
Q1) Do I need a visa to visit Guernsey?

A1) The Bailiwick of Guernsey is part of the Common Travel Area (CTA), along with the other Channel Islands, the Isle of Man, Republic of Ireland and the UK and therefore maintains the same standard of immigration controls. If you have a UK visit visa, then this will also allow you to visit the Bailiwick of Guernsey and the other Crown Dependencies (Jersey and the Isle of Man). You do not need a separate visa.

Please check this guidance on any visa requirements you may have:- Check if you need a UK visa - GOV.UK (www.gov.uk) or UK_Visa_requirements_July_2023.pdf

This also means that if you are working in the UK or one of the other Crown Dependencies then you may visit other areas without the need for any further permission. You cannot however take employment or live in another jurisdiction without approval from that authority.

Q2) Do I need a work permit to work in Guernsey?

A2) If you are a non-British or Irish Citizen then you must have permission to take employment here in the Bailiwick of Guernsey. Please refer to our Employment Permit Policy guidance

Q3) Do Guernsey issue Biometric Residency Cards (BRPs)?

A3) No, we grant permission to remain via letter and wet ink endorsement (a stamp in a persons passport).

Q4) I am a foreign national and I have spent some time in the UK on a Skilled worker visa. I now hold a work permit to take employment in Guernsey. Will my time spent in the UK count towards Indefinite Leave to Remain/settlement (ILR)?

A4) Yes, anytime spent lawfully in approved employment in either the UK, Bailiwick of Jersey or the Isle of Man will count towards the 5 years residency requirement required to be eligible for ILR

Q5) I hold settlement status under the European Union Settlement Scheme (EUSS) of which was granted in Guernsey. Can I work in the United Kingdom, Jersey or the Isle of Man?

A5) Yes, your settled status applies equally in the United Kingdom, Jersey and the Isle of Man. You will likely need to provide an employer or landlord this link so that they can verify your status:- View and prove your immigration status: get a share code - GOV.UK (www.gov.uk)

You may need to contact the United Kingdom Visas and Immigration (UKVI) customer services on 0300 790 6268 (fees may apply) to explain your situation and request guidance on how to register.

If you were granted EUPS (pre-settled) or EUSS under the scheme by another authority it also applies equally here in the Bailiwick of Guernsey. Please contact us with your details so that we may update our records accordingly.

Q6) I am a foreign national who was previously resident in Guernsey. I have moved to the UK and I am being asked for a "Share code" by UK based employers & landlords.

A6) You will likely need to provide an employer or landlord this link so that they can verify your immigration status:- View and prove your immigration status: get a share code - GOV.UK (www.gov.uk) or Prove your right to rent in England: Get a share code online - GOV.UK (www.gov.uk). You can then provide this link to an interested party so that they may view your immigration status https://www.gov.uk/check-immigration-status.

You may need to contact the United Kingdom Visas and Immigration (UKVI) customer services on 0300 790 6268 (fees may apply) to explain your situation and request guidance on how to register.

Q7) I am a foreign national and I need to evidence to my own government that I have not acquired British Citizenship. How can I evidence this?

A7) You will need to follow this link:- Apply for proof that you do not have British citizenship (form NQ) - GOV.UK (www.gov.uk)

Q8) Where can I sit the Life in the United Kingdom and Islands test in Guernsey?

A8) Please contact the Guernsey Training Agency Exam Centre | GTA. Please ensure you view and study our local Guernsey supplement from our website in addition to the Home Office publication entitled "Life in the United Kingdom - A Guide to New Residents (Third Edition, 2013"

Q9) What visa do I need to apply for?

A9) Please click here for visa guidance for the Bailiwick of Guernsey.

Q10) What is the status of a person granted leave to remain in Guernsey when they are in the UK?

A10) Schedule 4 of the United Kingdom Immigration Act 1971 covers the integration of the immigration laws of the United Kingdom and Islands. Schedule 4 provides that where a person has been given leave to enter or remain by the authorities of the Bailiwick of Guernsey, that leave, and any condition attached to it, will be treated as if it had been imposed in the United Kingdom. Please follow this link to our downloads section for further information regarding Schedule 4.

Q11) The UK Border Force have endorsed my passport. Can I check this is correct?

A11) An open date stamp is a stamp that you can expect to have placed in your passport by UK Border Force. If the endorsement is anything different or contains any new conditions of stay, or length of stay please contact us so we can check that everything is in order with your conditions.
